title: Question 112

children: A 19-year-old man is evaluated for an itchy, scaly eruption on the back of his neck of 2 months' duration. Last week, he self-treated with over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream; this seemed to reduce the itching and inflammation, but the rash expanded, and a new area of involvement appeared on the posterior neck. He has no other symptoms.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The characteristic finding of tinea infection is annular scaly patches with central clearing and varying degrees of inflammation; patients can experience pruritus, burning, or no sensation at all.
A definitive diagnosis of tinea is made with a potassium hydroxide scraping of the scale showing branching hyphae.
This patient has a superficial dermatophyte infection of the skin known as tinea corporis (

). The characteristic finding of tinea infection is annular scaly patches with central clearing and varying degrees of inflammation. Patients can experience pruritus, burning, or no sensation at all. A definitive diagnosis is made with a potassium hydroxide scraping of the scale showing branching hyphae. Appropriate treatment is topical antifungal agents. This patient used an over-the-counter topical glucocorticoid and temporarily reduced the inflammation, which made his skin feel less irritated. Despite the impression of improvement, however, these agents do not treat the underlying condition and can delay diagnosis.
Early localized Lyme disease often presents with erythema migrans (

), an annular red skin lesion that often has central clearing. It typically is asymptomatic, but some patients report burning. The most common locations are the axilla, inguinal region, popliteal fossa, and belt line. Erythema migrans is not associated with scale and will not respond to topical glucocorticoids.
The skin findings of nummular dermatitis (

) are eruptions of extremely pruritic, well-demarcated, round eczematous patches that usually occur on the lower extremities. The lesions can be acutely inflamed and start to weep. Diagnosis can be confirmed by skin biopsy if there is doubt. Early lesions of tinea corporis can mimic nummular dermatitis, but this patient has developed a scale on the lesion, making nummular dermatitis unlikely.

Subcutaneous lupus erythematosus may be idiopathic, occur in association with systemic lupus erythematosus, or be drug related. The decrease in inflammation in response to topical glucocorticoid and the presence of scale and central clearing are more suggestive of tinea corporis.

references: Kaushik N, Pujalte GG, Reese ST. Superficial fungal infections. Prim Care. 2015;42:501-16.
